Description: Fragment of wall of North Ionian black-figured pottery bowl. Clay drab brownish grey, with cream slip on outside; paint dull brown, fired greyish in parts; additions in purplish red and white. Inside glazed and decorated in 'Vroulian' manner: central, three white lines and two red bands; above and below and parts of incised floral chains(?), picked out with added rows of white dots and red and white details. Exterior: sphinx or griffin to right (head missing), with part of a second animal visible at left and blobs in field; red patches surrounded by double incisions on hind leg, red on alternate wing feathers and on neck; below, black band with added red band lined in white; top of another frieze below.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Hayes 1992, 204, N5: "Ware similar to Klazomenian (cf. N28). Probably from a dinos similar to Kinch, Fouilles de Vroulia pl. 15 (= Walter-Kardyi, Samos vi 1 pl.115 no. 941) though perhaps more open in form. Kardara's 'Mixed Technique' style (Rang 199ff), unattributed. For other similar Naukratis finds see Venit, Naukratis no.30,46 pp.11,15-16, 145, 150 pls. 8,12."
Bibliographic references: Hayes 1992 / Greek and Greek-Style Pottery and Plain Pottery in the Royal Ontario Museum; Excluding Black-Figure and Red-Figure Vases (p. 204 no. N5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.398)
